Review Multivalent metal–sulfur batteries for green and cost-effective energy storage: Current status and challenges Yue Yang a Haoyi Yang a Xinran Wang a ⁎ Ying Bai a Chuan Wu a b ⁎ a Beijing Key Laboratory of Environmental Science and Engineering, School of Materials Science & Engineering, Beijing Institute of Technology, Beijing 100081, China Beijing Key Laboratory of Environmental Science and Engineering School of Materials Science & Engineering Beijing Institute of Technology Beijing 100081 China Beijing Key Laboratory of Environmental Science and Engineering, School of Materials Science & Engineering, Beijing Institute of Technology, Beijing 100081, China b Collaborative Innovation Center of Electric Vehicles in Beijing, Beijing 100081, China Collaborative Innovation Center of Electric Vehicles in Beijing Beijing 100081 China Collaborative Innovation Center of Electric Vehicles in Beijing, Beijing 100081, China ⁎ Corresponding authors at: Beijing Key Laboratory of Environmental Science and Engineering, School of Materials Science & Engineering, Beijing Institute of Technology, Beijing 100081, China. Beijing Key Laboratory of Environmental Science and Engineering School of Materials Science & Engineering Beijing Institute of Technology Beijing 100081 China Graphic abstract Novel design of multivalent metal-sulfur batteries opens up opportunities for green, energy-dense and cost-effective energy storage with wide applications, such as power gird and portable devices. Multivalent metal–sulfur (M-S, where M = Mg, Al, Ca, Zn, Fe, etc.) batteries offer unique opportunities to achieve high specific capacity, elemental abundancy and cost-effectiveness beyond lithium-ion batteries (LIBs). However, the slow diffusion of multivalent-metal ions and the shuttle of soluble polysulfide result in impoverished reversible capacity and limited cycle performance of M−S (Mg–S, Al–S, Ca–S, Zn–S, Fe–S, etc.) batteries. It is a necessity to optimize the electrochemical performance, while deepening the understanding of the unique electrochemical reaction mechanism, such as the intrinsic multi-electron reaction process, polysulfides dissolution and the instability of metal anodes. To solve these problems, we have summarized the state-of-the-art progress of current M−S batteries, and sorted out the existing challenges for different multivalent M−S batteries according to sulfur cathode, electrolytes, metallic anode and current collectors/separators, respectively. In this literature, we have surveyed and exemplified the strategies developed for better M−S batteries to strengthen the application of green, cost-effective and high energy density M−S batteries. Keywords Multivalent metal-sulfur batteries Cost-effectiveness Green energy storage Shuttle effect Electrolyte 1 Introduction Since the first Industrial Revolution, there is an overwhelming increase in the need for energy. Renewable energy resources, such as biological and geothermal energy, compensate for the deficiencies and shortage of conventional fossil fuels, which have potentially fulfilled the social sustainable development. Nowadays, these renewable energies have already become practically available and achieved promising environmental benign. However, due to the fluctuation of natural resources, their intermittent power supply has blocked the large-scale utilization and the stability of electrical grid. Such unique problem has triggered wide attention to the adaptable rechargeable batteries for energy storage [1–3]. On this matter, lithium-ion batteries (LIBs), such as LiCoO2/graphite or Li(Ni0.8Co0.1Mn0.1)O2/graphite, have dominated the current choice of rechargeable batteries owing to the acceptable energy density and lifespan [4,5]. Nevertheless, large-scale use of LIBs has been potentially restrained by the low contents of lithium, cobalt, and other rare metals, the reserves of which may not be sufficient to support the rapid demands of LIBs manufacturing. Meanwhile, the energy density of current LIBs, which is the most essential parameter for rechargeable batteries, has already approached to the upper limit (~300 Wh kg−1). New electrodes and systems based on abundant and cost-effective elements are urgently required to break through these obstacles [6,7]. For a certain electrode material, the theoretical specific capacity can be determined by Eq. (1) as follows [8,9]: (1) Capacity ( C ) = n F / 3.6 M , where C, F, n, and M represent the theoretical capacity of the electrode material, the Faraday constant, the total electron transferred, and the molar mass of the electrode material, respectively. According to Eq. (1), reducing M or increasing n are both effective ways to improve energy density. In order to maximally fulfill the criteria, in this regard, sulfur is highlighted because of relatively low molar weight [10–13], two-electron transfer [14], and high crustal content [15,16]. It can provide a theoretical specific capacity as high as 1672 mAh g−1 [17] with respect of Li+, triggering wide interests to its alloying-type electrode reaction [18–21]. For example, the lithium–sulfur (Li–S) battery has become the most widely-explored M−S battery systems with continuous outcomes and performance upgradation. However, the current status of Li–S battery is still subject to many other restrictions, such as the scarcity of lithium resources and safety issues [22–25]. Even with relatively lower theoretical energy density, the researches on light-weight univalent metal-sulfur batteries, such as potassium–sulfur (K–S) and sodium–sulfur (Na–S) batteries, can alleviate the shortage of lithium resources. For comparison, when coupled with a sulfur cathode, light-weight multivalent metals can alternatively provide an even higher theoretical specific capacity, such as magnesium (Mg) and aluminum (Al) with a theoretical volumetric capacity of 1820 and 2424 Ah L−1, respectively [26–28]. Furthermore, the volumetric energy density of magnesium–sulfur (Mg–S) and aluminum–sulfur (Al–S) batteries even surpass that in Li–S (Fig. 1 ), which are particularly available for stationary energy storage and smart grid regulation [29,30]. Though being promising, these M−S batteries suffer from fundamental problems: (1) the elemental sulfur has intrinsically poor electronic conductivity [31]; (2) both sulfur cathode and multivalent metallic anode occur multi-electron reactions with insufficient electrochemical kinetics [32–34]; (3) passivation of these metal anodes generally blocks the ion/electron transfer, requiring corrosive electrolyte systems yet with minimum side reactions [35]; (4) shuttle effect of sulfur destroys the interface stability, induces low coulombic efficiency, and shortens the operational lifespan of multivalent M−S batteries [32,36,37]. The purpose of this article is to summarize the development of mainstream Mg–S, Al–S, and other novel types of multivalent M−S batteries. Concerning the problems that multivalent M−S batteries encounter, we consequently disclose the reaction mechanisms of sulfur, thoroughly explain the current progress in terms of electrolytes, electrodes and separators, and briefly introduce the strategy to enhance the overall battery performances. Last but not least, the metal electrodes design and interface issues are introduced, which have become the detrimental factor to typical M−S batteries with passivated interlayers during electrochemical process. Meanwhile, we summarize the current status and promising perspectives of multivalent M−S batteries upon the great development and research opportunities in future. 2 Mg–S Batteries Toyota Motor research group [38] reported the first rechargeable Mg–S battery in 2011. They synthesized a non-nucleophilic electrolyte through the reaction of hexamethyldisilazide magnesium chloride (HMDSMgCl) and aluminum trichloride (AlCl3). The as-formed active molecular species [Mg2(µ-Cl)3·6THF]+ can guarantee the reversibility of Mg2+/Mg. It is revealed from this research that the regulation of electrolytes plays a significant part in the success of the Mg–S battery. In 2014, researchers found that the electrolytes containing magnesium(II) bis(trifluoromethane sulfonyl) imide [Mg(TFSI)2], [Mg2(Cl)3] [HMDSAlCl3]− active species [39,40] can also realize the Mg stripping/deposition. It contributes to an excellent anodic stability by forming an appropriate solvation sheath structure based on ion–dipole interaction to dissociate the highly concentrated Mg salt. Till now, several other types of research have been also carried out on sulfur cathode, Mg anode and the electrolytes, promoting the development of Mg–S system. For example, the sulfur cathode modification can synergistically mitigate the overcharge behavior, ameliorate sulfur utilization and improve its compatibility with the electrolyte. The research direction and progress highlighted in the case of Mg–S batteries over the last ten years have been summarized as follows (Fig. 2 ), including the sulfur-carbon composite cathodes, electrolyte regulation, functional separator modification and advanced current collector design. We elaborate on the status and problems of the cathode from the electrolyte, current collector, and separator aspects, respectively. 2.1 Cathode materials Analogous to Li–S battery, the problem of the cathode in M−S battery includes the shuttle effect of sulfur [50], which causes the low sulfur utilization, poor coulombic efficiency [51], and the attenuated battery life [13]. The charge/discharge mechanism of polysulfide is summarized and the mostly-applied sulfur–carbon composites are introduced to enhance electrochemical performance by suppressing the diffusion of polysulfide. 2.1.1 Charge/discharge mechanism of polysulfide At present, there is no well-defined reaction path for Mg and sulfur to form Mg polysulfide. Scholars generally believe that the reaction mechanism is similar to that of the Li–S battery. Mg polysulfide with different chain lengths (such as MgS4, Mg3S8, and MgS2) are formed in multi-step reactions [40,52]. Specifically, the electrochemical reaction path of the Mg–S battery in the first cycle is shown in Fig. 3 b by using (HMDS)2Mg-2AlCl3-MgCl2/tetraacetamine electrolyte and sulfur/CMK-3 composite cathode (Fig. 3a) [40]. In particular, S8 is first reduced to the polysulfide S8 − and dissolved into the electrolyte, then gradually reduced to S6 − and S4 − to form a stable phase MgS4. During the discharging process, a plateau of ~ 1.5 V appears, corresponding to a specific capacity of 370 mAh g−1 [40]. This process can be written as follows: (2) S 8 + 4 e - + 2 M g 2 + = 2 M g S 4 The stable liquid MgS4 intermediate continues to be transformed into MgS2 solid phase, contributing to the second discharging stage of ~ 0.9 V with a specific capacity of 420 mAh g−1 (Fig. 3b and Eq. (3)) [40]. The final process associates with the reduction of the MgS2 solid phase into a stable MgS phase. (3) 2 M g S 4 + 4 e - + 2 M g 2 + = 4 M g S 2 (4) 2 M g S 2 + 4 e - + 2 M g 2 + = 4 M g S These three steps reflect the multiple-phase transition reactions and valence changes involved in the initial discharge process. More recent, Gao et al. [52] studied the thermodynamics, reaction pathway, and related kinetics of the Mg–S battery by using activated carbon clothes (ACC)/sulfur cathode and MgTFSI2-1,2-dimethoxyethane (DME) electrolyte. According to their observation, the sulfur reduction could be divided into three steps: (1) the sulfur element is first reduced to the polysulfide (S8 −) chain, showing a slope voltage drop to 1.5 V without an obvious discharge platform. (2) The S8 − is further reduced, and the liquid–solid phase transformation (according to the electrospray-ionization mass spectrometry) [52] is realized from S8 − to MgS2, which has a stable discharge plateau of 1.5 V. (3) The final step of solid-phase transformation from short-chain polysulfide MgS2 to MgS. The MgS2–MgS transition process is suffering from large kinetic barriers and high polarization with a voltage drop of 1.5–0.5 V [52]. The corresponding reaction mechanism of sulfur is shown in Fig. 3(c–f). The composite cathode materials of CMK-3/sulfur and ACC/sulfur have very similar electrochemical reaction mechanisms under different electrolyte conditions. Furthermore, in 2019, Xu and his collaborative research team [48] discovered the fading mechanism by studying the properties of polysulfide through the spin-polarized density functional theory (DFT) method. The structures of Mg x S8 (x = 1, 2, 3, 8) are amorphous, while the most stable structure MgS is crystalline [48]. The results of in-situ X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) measurements (Fig. 3g–j) show that the conversion from Mg3S8 to elemental sulfur is irreversible. After the first cycle, the conversion from Mg3S8 to MgS contributes to the major reversible capacity of about 400 mAh g−1 because MgS is unfortunately electrochemically inactivated [48]. The study on the electrochemical mechanism of the Mg–S battery system can theoretically grasp the reaction mechanism of amorphous phase formed by intermediate products and overcome the shuttle effect of Mg polysulfide, but it still requires more effort and insights. 2.1.2 Sulfur-carbon composite cathodes The structural design of sulfur cathode in Mg–S battery draws lessons from the Li–S battery system. The sulfur-carbon composites are still the most effective cathodes to synergistically improve the conductivity and the utilization of sulfur [54–56]. In 2011, Hee-Soo Kim from Toyota [38] proposed a pioneering work to introduce sulfur/carbon black composite materials into Mg–S battery. A variety of carbon substrates have been applied accordingly for the encapsulation of sulfur-based and polysulfides. The most representative work is proposed by Nazar group [53] in 2009, which first introduced the CMK-3/sulfur composites to M−S batteries. After fully mixing CMK-3 with sulfur, the mixture was evaporated at 155 °C for 12 h to sublimate the sulfur-based materials into mesoporous materials with a pore size of 3–4 nm. This compositing process can improve the electrical conductivity, and immobilize polysulfide inside the mesopore to restrain the polysulfide shuttle (Fig. 3a) [53]. Maximilian Fichtner group [40] further optimized the preparation process by pretreating CMK-3 with concentrated nitric acid and uniformly covering the CMK-3/sulfur surface with polyethylene glycol (PEG). The effect of confining sulfur was greatly improved because of additional heat treatment at 400 °C [40]. Other carbon materials, such as carbon nanotubes (CNTs) [57], CNFs [39,58], graphene-based nanostructures (Fig. 4 a) [45], and ACC [48,59,60], have been also used in Mg–S batteries. In addition, other types of carbon materials have been also applied, broadening other possible directions for sulfur-carbon compositing. Du et al. [61] synthesized sulfur-based graphdiyne (SGDY) materials as a cathode with all phenyl complex (APC) electrolytes. Graphdiyne is a layered structure composed of benzene rings and connected by butadiyne linkages [61] (shown in Fig. 4b), which can immobilize sulfur and its polysulfide into nanostructures. The designed SGDY cathode can achieve an initial discharge capacity of 1125 mAh g−1 and maintain a cycle capacity of 540 mAh g−1 after 35 cycles [61]. But there was serious overcharge phenomenon in the system, and the battery failed after 36 cycles (Fig. 4d) possibly due to electrolyte consumption or battery corrosion [61]. The use of metal–organic framework (MOF) and its derivatives is another example to achieve a high-performance Mg–S battery by nanostructuring with carbon materials. Zhou and coworkers [62] introduced MOF–templated carbon as a sulfur host with nitrogen and cobalt doping (Fig. 4e and f) that could trap polysulfide through strong chemical interactions. The ZIF-C-S composite will inspire more researchers to pursue the design of a framework, which possess ultrahigh surface area and diverse structural topologies. The unique architecture is beneficial for infiltration of sulfur as well as charge and mass transfer during electrochemical reaction. One-dimensional and two-dimensional carbon materials with a large surface-volume ratio are also mentioned to be promising regarding the polysulfide dissolution. By applying nitrogen-doped hybrid nanocomposite of multiwall carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) and graphene, the Fichtner research team [63] designed cathode hosts for Mg–S batteries. These more accessible conductive host matrix can also improve the restriction of polysulfides and supply an efficient charge transport [63]. Such nanocomposite has advantage of high Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area of 644 m2 g−1 (Fig. 4g) with sulfur loading of 76.2 wt%. In the sulfur loading of 3 mgsulfur cm−2, the battery can deliver an initial capacity of 431 mAh g−1 (Fig. 4h) and a reversible capacity of 228 mAh g−1 after 50 cycles at a current rate of 0.02C (Fig. 4i) [63]. 2.2 Electrolytes The ideal properties of electrolytes for Mg–S batteries should include: (1) High ionic conductivity with high permittivity and low viscosity; (2) Chemical and electrochemical stability with relatively wide electrochemical window; (3) Good thermal stability in a broad range of temperature; (4) Sufficient interface stability with electrodes and current collectors; (5) Safety, environmental protection, and low cost. For the exploitation of new electrolytes, it is still challenging to meet the criteria of (1), (2), and (4). Especially for Mg–S batteries, it is difficult to find suitable electrolytes to cover the theoretical potential of magnesium and sulfur reactions while realizing sufficient reaction reversibility. Additionally, the electrolyte should be ideally side-reaction free while being poor solvents for polysulfide dissolution. At present, the commonly used electrolyte of Mg batteries are nucleophilic, but the sulfur cathodes are unfortunately incompatible with nucleophilic electrolytes [64,65]. Therefore, it is particularly important to develop new types of non-nucleophilic electrolytes for the Mg–S battery. 2.2.1 Non-nucleophilic electrolyte The non-nucleophilic electrolyte of Hauser base-derived magnesium HMDSMgCl and AlCl3 has proved the feasibility of Mg–S battery for the first time [38], which opens up a new way for the exploitation of non-nucleophilic electrolyte for Mg–S battery. They modified HMDSMgCl electrolyte to form an active species of [Mg2(µ-Cl)3][HMDSAlCl3] (Fig. 5 a) [38]. The characteristics of cyclic voltammetry tests are shown in Fig. 5(b) among unmodified HMDSMgCl, in-situ generated [Mg2(µ-Cl)3][HMDSAlCl3] and [Mg2(µ-Cl)3][HMDSAlCl3] electrolytes, which were purified and crystallized by tetrahydrofuran (THF) solvent. The potential stability of [Mg2(µ-Cl)3][HMDSAlCl3] electrolyte was greatly increased from 2.5 to 3.3 V after purification by THF. This significant increase in potential stability was resulted from the purification step to remove unreacted HMDSMgCl in the electrolyte, which starts to decompose at 2.5 V [38]. The cycle performance of the battery (Fig. 5c) shows that the initial open-circuit voltage (0.55 V) is quite different from the theoretical one (1.77 V). It largely results from the oxide layer on the Mg electrode. The initial discharge capacity reached up to 1200 mAh g−1 [38], whereas a rapid decrease of discharge capacity occurred at the second cycle (394 mAh g−1). Fichtner and coworkers [40] further developed a different approach of one-step reaction between hexamethyldiishydrazine, [(HMDS)2Mg] and AlCl3 in diglyme (DEG) and tetraglyme (TEG). These reaction species prevents the formation of metal–carbon bonds and yields an Mg complex [40]. It was found that the [Mg2Cl3][HMDSAlCl3] active species formed accordingly, which supported the successful deposition and dissolution of Mg (Fig. 5d) [40]. Furthermore, by adding ionic liquid (IL) of N-methyl-N-butylpiperidinium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)imide (PP14TFSI), the solubility of the Mg polysulfide might be declined due to the weak coordinating of TFSI− in ILs with relatively low donor numbers [40] (Fig. 5e). The comparison shows that the electrochemical performance of IL-containing electrolyte is better and two discharge plateaus are presented similar to that of Li–S batteries (Fig. 5f). Using this optimized electrolyte with DEG and PP14TFSI, the initial discharge capacity of the Mg–S battery can reach up to 800 mAh g−1 and the specific capacity remains 280 mAh g−1 after 20 cycles (Fig. 5g) [40]. The electrochemical reversibility of discharge products in the electrolyte is important to realize the long cycle of Mg–S batteries. In 2015, Gao et al. [44] added LiTFSI to the 0.1 M (HMDS)2Mg-2AlCl3-MgCl2 electrolyte, and the mixed electrolytes can enable a reduced voltage hysteresis, showing a stabilized discharge plateau at 2.8 V (Fig. 5h). By sharp contrast, the discharge specific capacity of the LiTFSI-free electrolyte is only about 10 mAh g−1. Due to the formation of hybrid magnesium-lithium polysulfide (MgLi–PS), the kinetic barrier of the Mg polysulfide system decreases, and a discharge capacity of 1000 mAh g−1 can be maintained at 0.03C for more than 30 cycles [44]. Attempts have also been made for the development of novel Mg–S electrolytes by introducing organic magnesium borates-based electrolyte (OMBB) from tris(hexafluoroisopropyl) borate (B[HFP]3), MgCl2, and Mg powder in dimethyl ether [46]. The electrolytes contain different active species in the form of [Mg4Cl6(DME)6]2+, and tetra(hexafluoroisopropyl) borate anion ([B(HFP)4]−) (Fig. 6 a) [46], which can effectively reduce the energy required for Mg deposition and improve the reversible cycling of the system. Under the optimal condition [46], the potential stability on platinum can reach up to 3.3 V (vs. Mg/Mg2+) (Fig. 6b). Furthermore, the deposition/dissolution polarization is lower than 0.11 V (Fig. 6c). The compatibility of the electrolytes with different sulfur-based cathode materials was also examined, and the sulfur/CNT cathode material presents the optimized specific capacity of 1000 mAh g−1 at 0.1C (Fig. 6d). An original Mg bis(diisopropyl)amide (MBA)-based electrolytes have also been developed for Mg–S batteries [66]. By adjusting the ratio of MBA and AlCl3 in THF solution, the cycling performance of the rechargeable Mg–S batteries has been improved. Fig. 6e shows that the AlCl3 content improves the cycle stability of Mg–S battery to a great extent because the molar ratio of MBA to AlCl3 can affect the Mg plating/stripping and oxidative decomposition potential of the electrolytes [66], and the coulombic efficiency maintained at 99% after 200 cycles at a molar ratio of 1:2 (MBA/AlCl3). At the same time, the composite electrolyte with high AlCl3 content also shows excellent cycle stability and discharge specific capacity retention, which is better than APC nucleophilic electrolyte, i.e. (PhMgCl)2-AlCl3/THF (Fig. 6f). Interestingly, the researchers also explored the role of lithium chloride (LiCl) in the composite electrolyte [66]. Fig. 6(g and h) illustrates that the discharge plateau of the LiCl system is significantly increased to about 1.1 V and the discharge capacity can reach 800 mAh g−1, three to four times higher than that without LiCl. And the specific capacity remains 537 mAh g−1 after 30 cycles [66]. This proves the importance of lithium salt in Mg–S electrolyte, which can effectively reduce the content of Mg polysulfide and improve the oxidation kinetic energy barrier of the system. Adding appropriate additives is effective for electrolyte optimization. Gao et al. [58] added MgCl2 to the Mg(TFSI)2-based electrolyte in dimethoxyethane (DME). It can form [Mg2(μ-Cl)3]+active species, while chloride ion helps to remove the passivation layer on the Mg electrode [58]. Similarly, AlCl3 was added as Lewis acid to improve the deposition and dissolution of Mg and reduce the overpotential of the system [59], but the discharge capacity decreased rapidly after two cycles to about 50 mAh g−1 after 50 cycles. It was deduced to result from the insufficient reaction of sulfur in the electrolyte and the low dissociation of magnesium-ions. Meanwhile, Wang et al. [59] added LiCl and LiCF3SO3 to the electrolyte respectively, and found that the latter had a higher discharge specific capacity of 1200 mAh g−1 in the first cycle. After 50 cycles, the capacity is still about 400 mAh g−1. All these cases indicate that the selection of appropriate lithium salt additives can regulate the oxidation kinetics energy barriers of Mg polysulfides and greatly ameliorate the property of Mg–S battery. 2.2.2 Novel non-corrosive electrolyte Chlorides are generally considered to cause corrosion and side effects, which exist in most of the current electrolytes for Mg–S batteries. Therefore, it is of great significance to develop a new type of non-corrosive electrolyte. Li et al. [68] synthesized [Mg(THF)6][AlCl4]2 to replace MgCl2, which effectively restrains the corrosion of the system, but the cycle performance decreases to a certain extent. The initial discharge capacity can reach 700 mAh g−1 at 0.01C, but the cycle stability is not desired as only a capacity of 130 mAh g−1 remained after 19 cycles [68]. Inspired by the addition of AlCl3 as Lewis acid additives, Xu et al. [67] synthesized yttrium chloride (YCl3) type non-corrosive electrolyte (Fig. 7 a). Compared with aluminum-ion (Al3+), yttrium-ion (Y3+) has a lower standard electrode potential, which prevents Y3+ from depositing on the Mg electrode. In contrast to Al-based electrolytes, the YCl3 additive can inhibit the aggregation of MgS particles, which results in a conspicuously increased sulfur utilization (Fig. 7b and c). At the same time, YCl3 is very reactive with water to particularly eliminate trace water in the electrolyte, which inhibits the formation of the oxide layer on the surface of anode. Compared with the Al-based electrolyte where the battery attenuated to 50 mAh g−1 after 50 cycles, the capacity in such electrolyte can maintain above 900 mAh g−1 (Fig. 6i) [67]. Up to now, researchers continue to broaden the types of non-corrosive electrolytes, for example the weak coordination anion (WCAs) electrolyte with low nucleophilic and high solubility. Zhao-Karger research team [57] synthesized magnesium fluoroalkoxy borate electrolyte, which is considered to be a candidate WCAs electrolyte for Mg–S battery system. Moreover, Guo et al. [69] investigated the Mg/electrolyte interface, which is derived from two WCAs electrolytes: magnesium monocarborane (Mg(CB11H12)2) and Mg(TFSI)2. They found that Mg(CB11H12)2 has superior Mg plating-stripping property than that of Mg(TFSI)2. Due to the cathodic stability of (CB11H12)− anions, there is smooth deposition with almost no aggregated particles formed during Mg plating process (Fig. 7d–h). On the other hand, Mg (TFSI)2 has inferior performance because of its more severe passivation layer formation of MgS and S–O bonds (Fig. 7f and i). The current development trend of non-corrosive electrolyte and electrolyte additives is still far from the demand of commercialization that requires much attention and effort. 2.3 Magnesium anodes The metallic anode is one of the most essential components in the multivalent M−S battery system as the anode, greatly determining the long-term cycling of batteries. At present, most commercial LIBs use carbon materials as anode [35], while metallic anode regains the attention of researchers to achieve a high energy density of the cell up to 500 Wh kg−1. Likewise, Mg, Ca, Al, and other metals can be used as anodes for metal-ion batteries and multivalent M−S batteries, but they need to overcome some problems for practical use, such as poor compatibility between the metal anode and electrolyte, poor surface contact with the electrolyte, and poor cycle stability. Compared with reactive metals (Li and Na), Mg is stable in air and can be easily processed in general, which greatly improves the safety and stability of the battery. In the Mg batteries, polar non-proton solvents such as carbonate and nitrile can form a passivation layer that hinders the diffusion of metal ions on the electrode surface through self-hydrolysis or reaction with a trace amount of water. In different ether-based electrolytes, Hu et al. [70] observed the Mg deposition/stripping process at the anode/electrolyte interface of Mg–S batteries through electrochemical atomic force microscopy (AFM) (Fig. 8 a). The TEG-based electrolyte system showed better reversibility because the TEG system could reduce the desolvation process to achieve more uniform nucleation and crystallization, while the DEG system has rapid dynamics. At present, there are many studies on the electrolyte in the Mg batteries, but fewer researchers modify the Mg electrode to adapt the electrolyte and so on. Most of the electrode is composed of metal Mg, while a small part is a mixture of magnesium and carbon materials. Metallic Mg in form of Mg discs [39,71], plates [44], ribbons [59], or foils [39,46,57,60,62,72,73], provides magnesium sources for magnesium-ion batteries. These electrodes have dense surface layers that cause the poor contact of electrodes with the electrolyte and low utilization. To address the above issues, Friedrich and co-workers [74] proposed to use Mg and graphite powder to prepare powder-based Mg anode. They set the mass ratio of Mg powder to graphite powder at 4:1, different anodes were prepared by ball milling and hydraulic press under the conditions of 75 and 350 MPa, respectively [74]. In this regard, pressed anode at low pressure (PALP) had a higher specific surface area and better contact with the electrolyte, and the specific discharge capacity of PALP could reach 600 mAh g−1 in the first cycle. Another optimization idea of Mg anode refers to the intercalated anode material in LIBs [75–77], which can realize the intercalation and de-intercalation of Mg ions. In particular, intercalation compounds can reduce the anode volume expansion and inhibit the formation of magnesium oxide passivation film as well, but so far there is no related report on such application in Mg–S battery. The alloying phenomenon of Mg metal with other elements serves a novel direction for the Mg2+ and Mg–S battery, Liu and co-workers [75] used bismuth metal nanostructure alloyed anode material for magnesium-ion battery, it can adapt to the large volume change of the system and reduce the diffusion length of Mg2+ [75]. Similarly, a conductive interface can be designed on the surface of an Mg electrode concerning the current popular lithium metal battery artificial solid electrolyte interface (SEI), such as adding a conductive ultra-thin physically deposited atomic layer of Mg anode to inhibit the corrosion of Mg during charging [78]. 2.4 Current collector and separator modification for Mg–S battery The modification of current collectors and separators is obviously effective in stabilizing the sulfur cathode and metal anode interfaces. At present, collectors in LIBs are Al foil [79,80], copper foil [81,82], stainless steel foil [83,84] and surface carbon-coated Al foil [85,86]. Unfortunately, the electrolytes available for the Mg–S battery contain corrosive substances, such as halogen, so it is impossible to use these traditional current collectors. Theoretically, the copper foil will react with halogen-containing electrolytes. However, Zeng et al. [65] found that when copper was used as a current collector, the sulfur cathode can stably exist in nucleophilic electrolyte APC. It is because the Cu can react with sulfur to form Cu sulfides, and can provide a strong chemical interaction between Cu and sulfur, which increases its stability with nucleophilic electrolyte APC. Inspired by this work, other researchers found that copper foils can also be compatible with other electrolytes, such as OMBB [46] and MBA electrolyte [66]. In addition to the traditional current collector, the most commonly applied corrosion-resistant current collectors are molybdenum foil, titanium foil, carbon paper, and chromium-nickel–iron alloy Inconel 625. At present, only chromium-nickel–iron alloy Inconel 625 is used as the current collector in the Mg–S battery. Muthuraj et al. [47] creatively developed a kind of double-doped carbon cloth (DCC) that can not only resist corrosion but also absorb polysulfide as the current collector. The current collector with a three-dimensional porous structure has excellent conductivity and good stability. Using HMDS as electrolyte and S/rGO as a cathode material, the battery can offer a specific capacity of 388 mAh g−1 after 40 cycles [47]. The current collector for the future Mg–S battery is expected to possess high conductivity, high stability, adsorption of polysulfide, and high catalytic properties. The use of a modified separator is mainly to solve the shuttle effect of polysulfides. The main types of separators for traditional LIBs are polyethylene (PE) and polypropylene (PP), while the separators for M−S batteries are mainly glass fibers and other polymer separators, such as microporous polymer membranes. In Mg–S batteries, Yu et al. [73] proposed to use a CNF-modified glass fiber separator (Fig. 8b and c). The optimal discharge specific capacity of the CNF-modified battery system is approaching to 1200 mAh g−1, and the specific capacity maintains at 800 mAh g−1 after 20 cycles [73]. By comparison, the specific capacity of the unmodified separator battery can only reach 200 mAh g−1 after 20 cycles (Fig. 8d). The immobilization of polysulfide intermediates contributes to the improved stability and sulfur utilization. Metal sulfides are also used and proved to be effective to stabilize polysulfides in Mg–S batteries. Xu and co-workers [48] proposed to use a vacuum filtration process to modify the TiS2 layer on the separator. The introduction of the Ti–S bond and the catalysis of Ti atoms are able to absorb and catalyze polysulfide and improve the overall electrochemical kinetics. Furthermore, the researchers confirmed that the TiS2 can break the Mg–S bond and successfully reoxidize MgS and Mg3S8 back to higher-order polysulfides and S (Fig. 8e), and this structure can deliver 800 mAh g−1 for 30 cycles (Fig. 8f) [48]. 3 Al–S batteries The theoretical gravimetric capacity of Al metal reaches up to 2980 mAh g−1, with a volumetric capacity of 8040 mAh cm−3 [87], which is the highest among these light-weight multivalent metals. As an additional bonus, aluminum is the most abundant metal element in the earth’s crust, which is potential to be cost-effective [88,89]. Al–S battery combines the characteristics of light elements multi-electron reaction of both cathodes and anodes with great potentials for high energy density. Because of the amphoteric nature of Al, most electrolytes are not able to achieve feasible Al deposition and dissolution. The exception is the AlCl3-based ILs, which is capable of reversible Al deposition [90], and have been widely used for rechargeable aluminum batteries recently [91–97], therefore indirectly promotes the development of Al–S battery [98]. Archer et al. [99] proposed a rechargeable Al–S battery with such non-aqueous IL electrolytes. Inspired by their work, a series of achievements have been made in this field in the past six years. Wu et al. [100] developed a new type of Et3NHCl/AlCl3 IL electrolyte and optimized the performance by adding 1,2-dichloroethane (DCE), dichloromethane (DCM), and other additives, but the discharge specific capacity was limited to be only 1/10 of the theoretical one. In 2016, Wang and his colleagues [101] used the selected 1-ethyl-3-methylimidazolium chloride (EMICl)/AlCl3 (1:1.3) IL as the electrolyte and achieved a capacity of more than 1000 mAh g−1 for 20 cycles. Similarly, the research direction and highlighted progress of the Al–S batteries over the last six years have been summarized as follows (Fig. 9 ). 3.1 Cathode materials In the rechargeable Al–S battery, the strong solvation of multivalent Al3+ and extremely high intrinsic charge density will lead to slow diffusion and high reaction energy barrier, which leads to poor electrochemical kinetics and polarization of the battery. This part summarizes the current electrochemical behavior of polysulfide in IL electrolyte and the development of sulfur–carbon cathode, which improves electrochemical performance by suppressing the diffusion of polysulfide and increasing the conductivity of the cathode. 3.1.1 Electrochemical behavior of polysulfide in IL electrolyte In 2016, Wang et al. [101] put forward that the total reaction of the Al–S battery is a solid-state reaction process: 3 S + 2 A l = A l 2 S 3 , and it does not involve the multiphase reaction process. However, Manthiram et al. [103] proved that if the x number of S x 2− (1 ≤ x < 6) in the Al–S system is less than 6, it will be insoluble in EMICl/AlCl3 (1:1.3) IL electrolyte, and otherwise the S x 2− are soluble (Fig. 10 a). This shows that the dissolution of long-chain sulfur in the electrolyte can be controlled by optimizing of electrolyte, and the electrochemical reversibility of the Al–S battery can be improved by inhibiting the shuttle of short-chain sulfur through physical limitation and chemical bonding. At the same time, the poor conductivity of sulfur and the slow kinetics are also important factors that hinder the stable cycle of the battery. To solve these problems the design of efficient sulfur cathode materials is indispensable. 3.1.2 Sulfur–carbon composite cathodes Using carbon materials and sulfur composite is the most-applied approach to enhance the conductivity. In 2015, Archer et al. [99] designed the first rechargeable Al–S battery with non-aqueous IL as the electrolyte. The cathode was made by mixing sulfur element with carbon black (Ketjen black carbon) (Fig. 10b) and it delivered a discharge specific capacity of 1300 mAh g−1 after 6 cycles (Fig. 10c) [99], which shows the acceptable reversibility of Al–S battery. Wang et al. [101] optimized the electrolyte ratio and compounded sulfur with ACC, and they made sulfur sublimation evaporation into carbon pores (carbon pore diameter ≤ 2 nm) at 155 °C. Through these measures, the battery could achieve stable cycle stability of 20 cycles and deliver a capacity of more than 1000 mAh g−1 (Fig. 10d and e). When elevating the experimental temperature to 50 °C [101], the polarizations was greatly reduced (Fig. 10f) and the voltage hysteresis was declined to 0.5 V (Fig. 10g). Manthiram et al. [103] designed a new type of sulfur cathode structure and dispersed S/Al[EMI]Cl4 slurry onto CNF to construct self-assembled cathode materials. This structure can achieve maximum contact with active species in the electrolyte and inhibit the shuttle effect of polysulfide. At present, the most widely-used sulfur cathode in Al–S battery is CMK-3/sulfur composite (Fig. 11 a) [105,107], which restricts the sulfide in the channel and enhances the electrical contact of sulfur-based cathode materials. This structure can serve as a pathway for the reaction with sulfur and promote the redox kinetic process. Although great progress has been made by the cathode optimization [105], the overall stability of these Al–S prototypes is far from satisfactory (Fig. 11b). Despite this physical confinement by porous carbon materials, other adsorption materials, such as GO/rGO [108–111], MOF [112–114], and MXene [115–117], can inhibit polysulfides through chemical bonding. The MOF-modified composite cathode (immobilized sulfur on carbonized HKUST-1 (sulfur/HKUST-1-C)) can form Cu x S ion clusters with polysulfides. The strong interaction between the polysulfides and the Cu nanoparticle surface can enhance the reversibility of sulfur in the charge and discharge process (Fig. 11c) [102]. Besides, the Cu in HKUST-1 also increases the electronic conductivity of the cathode interface, which narrows the kinetic barrier in the electrochemical conversion process. In this system, it can deliver a high discharge specific capacity of 1200 mAh g−1 in the first cycle (Fig. 11d) with a reversible capacity of 460 mAh g−1 after 500 cycles (Fig. 11e) [102]. Similarly, Guo et al. [118] used Co as an electrochemical catalyst which formed cobalt sulfides to increase the reaction activity and reduce the voltage hysteresis. Despite sulfur–carbon composites, other new composites of metal nanoparticles [119], sulfur-based materials [120], and self-assembly systems [121] are the potential directions to enhance the electrical conductivity and realize the physical limitation and chemisorption of polysulfides. 3.2 Electrolytes 3.2.1 Ionic-liquid electrolytes The large polarization phenomenon (about 0.8–1 V) and slow dynamic process are typical characteristics of current Al–S battery systems, which refers to high voltage hysteresis and poor cycle stability. At the same time, the oxidation layer on the surface of Al anode is also considered to be a challenge to achieve sufficient cycle stability. The battery performance optimization is inseparable from the improvement of electrolytes. In 2015, Archer et al. [99] designed the first rechargeable Al–S battery, using AlCl3 and EMICl as the electrolyte. They investigated the electrochemical behavior of the Al–S battery by adjusting the different ratio of EMICl and AlCl3. A stable discharge platform of 1.2 V could be achieved at a molar ratio of 1:1.5 [99]. Based on such pioneering and inspiring work, Wu et al. [100] prepared a new type of IL by using (AlCl3)/(Et3NHCl) with toluene, benzene, DCM, and DCE. In the presence of DCM, it can achieve 40 stable cycles and the capacity retention rate is over 97%. However, the discharge specific capacity of this work can only reach 110 mAh g−1 (Fig. 12 a) [100], which is far from the theoretical one. Moreover, Wang et al. [101] and Manthiram et al. [103] found that when the ratio of EMICl/AlCl3 IL electrolyte reached up to 1.3:1, the electrochemical reversibility can be improved. The [Al2Cl7]− can ensure reversible deposition and dissolution of Al [122]. Other researches get very similar results and conclusion [123]. EMICl/AlCl3 (1.3:1) IL electrolyte can gurantee the reversibility of Al–S battery, but exhibited poor cycle performance. Lithium salt additives in the M−S battery system is another good choice for electrolyte optimization [44]. Reported by Manthiram et al. [104], adding lithium-ion to the electrolyte has elevated the formation of soluble polysulfide and reduced the electrochemical kinetic energy barrier of reduction or oxidation of Al polysulfide (Fig. 12b). The results of XPS analysis and DFT calculation showed that the existence of lithium-ion greatly improved the electrochemical reversibility by inhibiting the formation of Al = S bond during the discharge process and promoting the reactivation of sulfide species [104].This electrolyte system can achieve a discharge specific capacity of more than 1000 mAh g−1 in the first cycle and maintain a high discharge capacity of 600 mAh g−1 after 50 cycles (Fig. 12c). In this respect, the high charge density is another more prominent defect for high-valent Al–S batteries, leading to some other problems, such as low discharge capacity. Li et al. [107] used Al2Cl6Br− instead of Al2Cl7 − as a dissociation reagent. DFT calculation shows that the dissociation reaction of Al2Cl7 − to Al3+ at interface is replaced, and the dissociation reaction is accelerated (by almost 15 times) [107], as the dissociation energy barrier is greatly reduced (Fig. 12d and e). Furthermore, in the condition of a high discharge current density of 251 mA g−1, it can deliver a discharge capacity of more than 1500 mAh g−1 in the first cycle (Fig. 12f) [107]. Furthermore, using N-butyl-N-methyl-piperidinium (NBMP+) cations to replace all EMI+ cations in the Al–S battery. This structure achieves a high sulfur utilization and sustains a discharge capacity of 600 mAh g−1 after 20 cycles (Fig. 12g). The Al–S battery with the EMIBr/AlCl3 electrolyte shows inferior cycling performance owing to the side reactions between electrophilic polysulfide intermediates and the nucleophilic C2 carbon in the imidazole ring of EMI+ [107]. It is deduced that the substitution of NBMP+ with EMI+ cations could inhibit the side reaction of intermediate polysulfide products. 3.2.2 Low price and non-corrosive electrolyte system design The high price and extremely strong corrosive characteristics of imidazolium-type electrolyte are some of the important reasons that hinder the commercial use of Al batteries. In 2019, Yu et al. [105] synthesized a low eutectic solvent electrolyte by replacing imidazole salts with acetamides (AcA). The AcA electrolyte has the advantages of excellent cycling performance, low price, and reduced voltage polarization. The nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) analysis suggests a significant increase of the [AlCl2(AcA)2]+. Meanwhile, the DFT results indicate that the energy barrier of Al2Cl7 − species in the reaction was lower than that of [AlCl2(AcA)2]+ (Fig. 13 a and b) [105]. Therefore, the reaction mechanism is similar to EMICl/AlCl3 electrolyte yet with more desirable kinetics. However, the side reaction derived from the AcA-type electrolyte needs to be further improved. Furthermore, John et al. [106] studied the effect of different kinds of electrolytes on the side reaction of Al–S battery. The obtained discharge capacity was higher than the theoretical one (Fig. 13c and d) when acetalumina and uralumina were introduced into electrolytes. They proposed that acetalumina and uralumina could not exist stably, and the corresponding side reaction attributed to the additional discharge capacity [106]. The high viscosity of these electrolytes is another aspect that may limit the mass loading of the sulfur cathode and reduce the overall energy density of Al–S battery, as the deep eutectic electrolytes may not penetrate the electrode with certain thickness [106]. From the perspective of highly safety and environmental friendliness [124,125], the aqueous electrolyte has attracted wide attention. However, the oxide layer on the Al electrode and the hydrolysis of polysulfide in an aqueous electrolyte constitute the serious obstacles for the aqueous Al–S battery. In 2020, Hu et al. [126] developed an aqueous Al–S battery system which used the high concentration LiTFSI to prevent from the hydrolysis of Al polysulfide (Fig. 13e). In this configuration, the battery could deliver an initial capacity of 1410 mAh g−1 (Fig. 13f) and a reversible capacity of 420 mAh g−1 after 30 cycles (Fig. 13h) [126]. Actually, the development of Al–S battery electrolyte is still in its infancy. Addressing the issues of stability, kinetics, and other practical problems, especially to realize cost-effective and non-corrosive electrolytes, will make a significant contribution to the practical application of the Al–S battery system. 3.3 Aluminum anodes The multivalent, abundant and low-price Al metal should be an ideal anode material, and yet the application of Al is not as feasible as desired. The oxide film formed on the surface of Al is the most challenging issue for the effective Al deposition. As a result, contrast to lithium metal most researches on Al-ion batteries are still in the experimental stage [127-129], engaging to improve the kinetics and promote stability by developing new electrolytes systems. For most of studies, directly polished Al electrodes are utilized in order to exclude the possible cell failure by passivating oxide layers. Our team proposed in 2016 that the anode Al3+ pathway could be constructed by immersing halogen corrosive electrolyte, and coupled the activated Al anode with non-corrosive Al(OTF)/[BMIM]OTF to construct an Al battery system with high voltage and high electrochemical activity [130]. On the other hand, Al is likely to form dendritic protrusions during deposition, which will destroy the interface stability and even lead to cell failure and safety risks. In the Al batteries, Reed and co-workers [131] directly observed the formation of dendritic substances, and proved that the dendrites were composed of aluminum, iron, chlorine, and other elements. However, for the unpolished Al electrode, there were no corresponding reports to prove the presence of dendritic substances [131]. At present, it is considered that the passivation film reduces the nucleation sites of Al dendrites to a great extent so that Al dendrites will not grow unlimitedly on the surface of the metal anode [122]. A new type of Al battery system with Al alloy foil as the anode was reported by Jiao et al. [132]. The electrode potential of Mg-containing compounds in the alloy is more negative than that of Al, which is primarily dissolved in the reaction. Mg can alleviate hydrogen evolution and corrosion, thus enhancing the electrochemical capability of Al anode. Besides this, in contrast with the pure Al anode, the battery has a high efficiency and low-cost advantages. 3.4 Current collector and separator modification for Al–S battery The stability of the current collector in Al–S batteries should be highlighted because the electrolytes in Al–S batteries are highly corrosive imidazole salt-based ILs. In this case, the traditional Al foil, Cu foil, and stainless steel foil can not be used because of the side reaction with the electrolyte. At present, there is no related report on the application of functional collectors, which are similar to that used in the Mg–S battery system. In theory, catalytic current collector [133] can be used to promote the electrochemical kinetics of the Al–S battery while achieving high conductivity and stability. Similar to other M−S batteries, modification of separator is another approach to regulating the polysulfides shuttle in the Al–S system. Manthiram et al. [103,104] made a modified glass fiber separator with single wall carbon nanotubes (SWCNTs) (Fig. 14 a). It could significantly improve cycle stability and reduce the polarization of the Al–S battery (Fig. 12c). Inspired by the separator modification in the Li–S battery, rGO modification could inhibit sulfur and polysulfide by charge transfer, thus alleviating the shuttle effect [134]. Xiao et al. [135] designed a room-temperature Al–S battery with an rGO-coated separator. This structure (Fig. 14b) led to the reduced voltage hysteresis during cycling (Fig. 14c), which implied that the rGO coating acted as an upper current collector to the lower barrier of reaction kinetics [135]. 4 New emerging multivalent M−S batteries 4.1 Calcium–sulfur (Ca–S) batteries Calcium is the fifth most abundant element in the earth’s crust and has a high melting point, and it has the characteristic of a low cost compared with the traditional Li–S battery [136-139], so it will be a promising energy storage device in the future. The current study on Ca–S batteries focuses on electrolyte optimization and the corresponding mechanism. In 2013, Seshadri et al. [140] first reported a Ca–S battery with Ca(ClO4)2 electrolyte in acetonitrile (Fig. 15 a). The battery could deliver 600 mAh g−1 discharge specific capacity in the first cycle [140], but the SEI layer formed on the surface of the calcium electrode limited the reversibility and hindered the cycle stability (Fig. 15b). Manthiram et al. [141] proposed a reversible Ca–S battery system with a Ca(CF3SO3)2 and LiCF3SO3 hybrid electrolyte in tetraethylene glycol dimethyl ether (TEGDME) solvent, which synergistically improved the reversibility of electrode reaction and increased the utilization of sulfur cathode. The mechanism analysis showed that Li+ promoted the charge transfer of the reactions owing to it serves as a mediator-ion to facilitate the ionic charge transfer in the SEI layer [141] while reducing the impedance of the Ca–S battery. 4.2 Zinc–sulfur (Zn–S) and iron–sulfur (Fe–S) batteries Nowadays the aqueous Zn-ion batteries (ZIBs) have received widespread attention. Zhi et al. [142] reported the first reversible aqueous zinc–sulfur (Zn–S) battery in this field. A liquid film was developed, rendering the Zn2+-transfer channels and polysulfide cathode with better structural stability [142]. The Zn–S battery used the 4-(3-butyl-1-imidazolio)-1-butanesulfoni IL activated poly(Li2S6-random-(1,3-diisopropenylbenzene)) (poly(Li2S6-r-DIB) copolymer (abbreviated as PLSD) as the cathode (Fig. 15c), and it was synthesized by liquid-phase synthesis process at room temperature. The wettability of the cathode is closely related to the electronic and ionic conductivity of the electrode, which seriously affects the electrochemical reversibility of batteries [144]. As is shown in Fig. 15d, the PLSD electrode has poor electrolyte wettability, while the IL-PLSD electrode obtained by IL cast on the cathode shows good hydrophilicity (Fig. 15e) [133]. Moreover compared with PLSD and IL-PLSD used as the cathode, the LF-PLSD delivered an excellent capacity of 1148 mAh g−1 at 0.3 A g−1 [142]. Furthermore, the reversibility and cycle life of the Zn–S battery could be significantly improved by using a highly concentrated electrolyte. The addition of 21 M LiTFSI enables reactivation of short-chain ZnS2 and ZnS either through forming strong coordination of Li+ with the S2 2− and S2− in the form of Zn x Li y S3−8 or through converting them to Li2S2 and Li2S by ion exchange [142]. It increases ZnS2 and ZnS solubility, and reduces the kinetic barriers of re-oxidation. They also analyzed the mechanism of the battery which revealed that, upon discharging, S6 2− was dominantly reduced by Zn to S2− (S6 → S2−). These short chains were oxidized to form long-chain Zn x Li y S3−6 during charging [142]. A similar effort has also been paid on the Fe–S battery. Refering to the principle of Li–S battery [145–147], Ji et al. [143] has proposed the mechanism of Fe–S battery (Fig. 15f) that the redox mechanism of Fe–S battery is a solid–solid conversion process, which goes through consequent solid-phase transition S8 ↔ FeS2 ↔ Fe3S4 ↔ FeS (Fig. 15g) [143]. In the discharge process, S8 was gradually reduced to the final product FeS through FeS2 and Fe3S4 during this course. When the battery is charged, FeS firstly converts into a mixture of Fe3S4/FeS2, and then transforms to S8/FeS2. The incomplete transition during charging may be caused by poor electrode reversibility and slow dynamics [143]. The work revealed that the insolubility of iron sulfides in an aqueous solution is of great significance to the Fe–S battery, and it also provides a new idea to avoid the polysulfide shuttle. 5 Conclusions and outlook Here we backtrack the course of multivalent M−S batteries over the last ten years. First, challenges still exist for sulfur cathodes, such as poor conductivity, loss of active material, product volume expansion, and low sulfur utilization. The design principles of the sulfur cathode in Li–S batteries are also applicable to M−S batteries, among which surface physical limitation, chemisorptivity, conductivity, and carbon-based electrode porosity are anticipated to play crucial roles in regulating the above problem. Second, the optimization of the system is also inseparable from the combination with other components, and the electrolyte is also vital to M−S batteries due to the issues arising from the diverse metal/electrolyte interface. For instance, in the Mg–S battery, mainly to optimize the compatibility of Mg anode and sulfur-based cathode, non-nucleophilic electrolytes are free of side effects. These electrolytes are recognized as an appropriate option, especially that the development of chlorine-free or non-corrosive electrolytes is conducive to improve battery safety. At the same time, electrolytes containing boron and Al-based weakly coordinated anions can achieve high coulombic efficiency and long cycle due to the metal additives, such as lithium-ion mediation. In terms of Al–S batteries, the intrinsic high charge density and oxide surface film are essential factors to limit the selection of electrolyte. Researchers have always believed that IL electrolytes enable reversible Al plating/stripping at room temperature, but the high price and strong corrosive properties may hinder its commercialization. The emergence of deep eutectic solvents and high concentration aqueous electrolytes indeed promote the development of low-cost, safe, and non-corrosive electrolytes. For Ca–S, Zn–S, and Fe–S batteries, exploring stable electrochemical reversibility and high electrochemical window electrolytes will be a promising yet challenging direction in the future. Third, the metal anode is another key to the long cycle life of batteries, and the deposition process of these multivalent metals varies according to the types of metals and their pretreatment. For most Mg anodes, no dendrites would be formed in the charging process, which intrinsically determines the safety of the battery. On the contrary, it is well known that the passivation film is easily formed on the surface of the Al anode, and there are fewer penetration centers for untreated Al electrodes than polished ones. The electrolyte reacts with the metal through these penetration centers, which greatly reduces the nucleation position of Al dendrites so that Al dendrites will not grow infinitely. The sulfur battery with other metals as electrodes are less concerned by researchers, and the behavior of metal electrodes has yet been further clarified. There is no doubt that LIBs have made remarkable progress in the field of consumer electronics and electric mobility in recent years, but the shortcomings of cost, resource, and energy density are important factors that may limit its further development. The new M−S battery systems represented by the Al–S battery can provide competitive energy density. However, most M−S batteries have the problem of dissolution of intermediate polysulfide, which will cause overcharge, loss of active material, low sulfur utilization, and metal electrode failure. Here, we mainly focus on the reaction system of the multi-electron M−S batteries. Different from the mechanism of the Li–S battery, the electrochemical behavior of polysulfide is different due to the difference between the metal anode, electrolyte, and phase diagrams of M−S. Multiple bonds of metal–sulfur (e.g. Mg = S, Al = S, Fe = S, and Zn = S) always have high binding energy, which means that the final discharge product is electrochemically inactive and poor solubility with different electrolytes. The interaction mechanism between the electrolytes and the sulfur cathode is not clear, which is prone to side reactions and ultra-high discharge specific capacity. On the other hand, the discharge plateau obtained from experiments far below the theoretical one needs to be further studied, which may be affected by the sluggish kinetics, the side reactions of electrolyte, and the passivation of the metal electrode. It can be seen that although some progress has been made in many areas, there are still some important challenges, which are the driving force for the researchers, and will also become the direction of future research (Fig. 16 ), which means that we should pay more attention to new metal nanoparticles, self-assembly systems and covalent binding of sulfur to carbon cathode materials to inhibit the dissolution of sulfur and polysulfide. As for novel electrolyte design, the development of electrolytes is still in its infancy, especially in the efforts to the cost-effective and non-corrosive electrolyte. What’s more, looking for alloying anode materials and constructing ideal SEI film are feasible methods to improve the performance of multivalent metal anode. Despite we have made a lot of attempts, there is still a long way to go to achieve the high efficiency, stability, low price, and environment friendly multivalent M−S batteries. coredata.dc:description: Multivalent metal–sulfur (M-S, where M = Mg, Al, Ca, Zn, Fe, etc.) batteries offer unique opportunities to achieve high specific capacity, elemental abundancy and cost-effectiveness beyond lithium-ion batteries (LIBs). However, the slow diffusion of multivalent-metal ions and the shuttle of soluble polysulfide result in impoverished reversible capacity and limited cycle performance of M−S (Mg–S, Al–S, Ca–S, Zn–S, Fe–S, etc.) batteries. It is a necessity to optimize the electrochemical performance, while deepening the understanding of the unique electrochemical reaction mechanism, such as the intrinsic multi-electron reaction process, polysulfides dissolution and the instability of metal anodes. To solve these problems, we have summarized the state-of-the-art progress of current M−S batteries, and sorted out the existing challenges for different multivalent M−S batteries according to sulfur cathode, electrolytes, metallic anode and current collectors/separators, respectively. In this literature, we have surveyed and exemplified the strategies developed for better M−S batteries to strengthen the application of green, cost-effective and high energy density M−S batteries.

coredata.dc:title: Multivalent metal–sulfur batteries for green and cost-effective energy storage: Current status and challenges
